content:
The perception of a brand is often shaped by only a few key decades.
For Breitling, this is usually the aviation era, especially during the quartz crisis.

But there is much more to discover.
This lesson explores how Breitling evolved over time and built its reputation across different eras.

You’ll learn the milestones that define the brand and how to use them to tell a powerful story.

Breitling was founded in 1884 by Léon Breitling.
His goal: create the best instruments to measure time.

His son, Gaston, improved the design with the first independent chronograph pusher in 1915.
Later, Willy Breitling added elegance to functionality, launching the first modern chronograph in 1934.

These three generations shared a single vision: innovation in precision and design.

In 1934, Willy Breitling added a second independent pusher.
This changed watchmaking forever—almost all modern chronographs use this layout today.

Willy also believed that watches could be stylish, not just technical.
He shifted Breitling’s image: from tool to icon.

In the 1930s, Willy Breitling expanded the brand’s purpose.
He created onboard chronographs for both cars and airplanes.

These precision instruments helped pilots and drivers measure time with accuracy.
Breitling became a trusted name for military and civilian aviation.

In 1938, the Huit Aviation Department was created to meet military demands.
It focused on durable instruments with an 8-day power reserve.

This era solidified Breitling’s identity as a toolmaker for professionals.

The Huit Aviation Department played a key role during WWII.
Its instruments were used by the RAF and other air forces.

Today, Breitling honors this history with watches like the Super AVI Curtiss Warhawk.
This model links modern design with WWII-era innovation.

When you wear a Super AVI, you're wearing a piece of aviation history.

Willy Breitling believed watches should be emotional, not just functional.
In the 1940s, he introduced designs that combined purpose and style.

The Chronomat offered a slide rule for engineers.
The Premier was a refined wristwatch—luxurious, yet practical.

Wearing a Breitling became more than wearing a tool—it became a statement.

In 1944, Breitling launched the Datora—a complex calendar chronograph with moon phases.
It was elegant, innovative, and highly functional.

The Duograph followed, offering a split-second function for precise timing.

These watches reflected a new philosophy:
Function, yes—but also emotion and beauty.

In the mid-20th century, Breitling created legendary models for each environment:

- Navitimer for aviation
- Chronomat for engineers
- SuperOcean for divers

Each model belonged to a distinct universe: Air, Land, or Sea.
That concept still shapes Breitling collections today.

In 1952, Breitling introduced the Navitimer, a chronograph with a built-in slide rule.
It allowed pilots to perform flight calculations on the wrist.

It became the must-have for pilots, and remains an icon to this day.

The name blends “navigation” and “timer”—a true flight instrument.

In the 1960s, Willy Breitling created the Top Time collection.
It was bold, modern, and aimed at young professionals.

These watches weren’t just tools—they expressed style and personality.
Even women were drawn to the design’s elegance and originality.

Top Time marked a turning point in how watches connected with people emotionally.

In 1969, Breitling helped launch one of the first automatic chronograph movements: the Chrono-Matic.

This breakthrough changed how watches were powered—no more winding.
It combined performance with modern flair.

The movement was used across models, including new versions of the Navitimer.

This era was full of creative risks:
- Bullhead cases
- Square subdials
- Vivid colors
- Resin cases like the Sprint

Breitling watches reflected the era’s bold fashion trends.

Current models still borrow design cues from these adventurous years.

In the 1970s, quartz watches—especially from Japan—disrupted the Swiss market.
They were cheaper, more accurate, and easier to produce.

Traditional brands struggled. Jobs were lost. Factories closed.
Even Breitling released quartz models, like a digital Navitimer.

It was a time of uncertainty—but also opportunity.

In 1979, Ernest Schneider, a watchmaker and pilot, acquired Breitling.
He promised to keep it independent and true to its spirit.

He saw quartz not as a threat, but a tool.
Breitling would blend quartz precision with mechanical mastery.

This balance saved the brand—and helped define a new era.

Under Ernest Schneider, Breitling embraced a new motto:
“Instruments for professionals.”

The brand used quartz for precision and mechanical movements for heritage.
Breitling focused on pilot watches, positioning itself as a leader in aviation.

Instead of cheap mass-production, Breitling used quartz for high-performance tools.

In 1983, Breitling released the SuperOcean Deep Sea, water-resistant to 1000m.
Later, the Frecce Tricolori—a pilot squadron—asked Breitling to design a mechanical watch for their team.

This request gave birth to the modern Chronomat in 1984.
It marked the comeback of mechanical watches with style and performance.

In the 1990s, Breitling introduced SuperQuartz™, ten times more accurate than standard quartz.

They also released the Emergency, a revolutionary watch with a distress beacon.
Pilots could now signal for help from their wrist.

The Emergency became a symbol of survival and innovation.

In 1999, Breitling became the first brand to make every watch COSC-certified.
That means every movement was officially tested for precision.

This applied even to quartz models, something no other brand did.

It showed Breitling’s commitment to excellence—beyond trends.

To avoid supply chain risks, Breitling opened its own factory: Breitling Chronométrie.

In 2009, it launched its first in-house movement: the Breitling 01.
It offered a 70-hour power reserve and better reliability.

This was a key moment in the brand's technical independence.

In 2007, Breitling revived the SuperOcean Heritage line.
It kept the vintage look of the 1957 model, but with modern performance.

The Chronomat B01 44, launched shortly after, was the first to use the new movement.

Breitling was now a full-fledged manufacture—blending past and future.

Breitling kept pushing boundaries with the Emergency II,
the Exospace B55 smartwatch, and the Chronoworks® lab.

These innovations brought more safety, connectivity, and efficiency
to Breitling watches—while keeping the pilot’s spirit alive.

In 2017, Georges Kern became CEO and refocused the brand.
Breitling returned to its roots:
heritage, elegance, and storytelling.

Collections were simplified, design was refined, and new markets were explored.
The goal? Preserve legacy while modernizing the brand.
